svg:text.svg:tspan: Section Six — Improving and Marking Sample Answers
Mark the Answer
Here’s your first set of sample answers. For each one, think about where it fits in the mark scheme on
page 84. Most answers won’t fit the criteria for any one band exactly — it’s about finding the best fit.
Have a go at these
marking answer extracts
For each extract:
a) Write down the grade band (4-5, 6-7 or 8-9) you think the answer falls into.
b) Give at least two reasons why you chose that grade band.
‘No Problem’ and ‘The Class Game’ both use language to present personal identity. In his poem
‘No Problem’, Zephaniah uses phonetic dialect like “de”, “yu” and “dey” to show the speaker’s Caribbean
heritage. Words such as “branded” and “Mother country” also connect their personal experiences to wider
issues. In ‘The Class Game’, the speaker’s identity is shown in a similar way by using Liverpudlian dialect
like “corpy” and “wet nelly”, which show that they were raised in Liverpool. The use of colloquial words, for
example “bog” and “bum”, show that they are not posh or formal.
Answer Extract 1
Both poets consider how stereotypes affect personal identity. In ‘No Problem’, the juxtaposition of
the phrases “born academic” and “branded athletic” highlight how the speaker has been pushed down
a certain path to ﬁt with a stereotype rather than being allowed to express their personal identity. The
word “branded” has connotations of not only slavery, but also the branding of animals, which suggests
to the reader that this dehumanisation is a much more widespread issue. Similarly, Casey’s speaker
asks whether they have “a label” on their body telling people what class they are from. While the idea
of a label on someone’s “bum” is at ﬁrst humorous, by asking about a physical label, the speaker invites
the reader to think about the ﬁgurative ‘labelling’ of people. This reinforces the speaker’s message that
stereotypes lead to judgemental views that get in the way of appreciating an individual’s personal identity.
Answer Extract 2
Both poets use repetition to express personal identity in their poems. In ‘No Problem’, the speaker
repeats the phrase “I am not de problem”. This shows the speaker’s conﬁdence in their own identity
because, despite being a victim of racism, they repeatedly conﬁrm that they are more than a stereotype.
This repetition also makes the reader question whether they themselves are part of the problem and
if they contributed to the negative “conditions” that are explored in the poem. Similarly, in ‘The Class
Game’, the repetition of the question “How can you tell what class I’m from?” throughout the poem gives
the impression that the speaker is angry and frustrated, and causes the reader to question whether they
have any personal assumptions about social class.
Answer Extract 3
Q3
Compare how poets present personal identity in ‘No Problem’
and in
one
other poem from ‘Conﬂict’.
[20 marks]
